Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: ESCAPE: Experimental Study on Computer Architecture and Performance Evaluation

Award.AbstractNarration:
The three year REU Site program "ESCAPE: Experimental Study on Computer Architecture and Performance Evaluation" at the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA) will focus on research for computer architecture, VLSI design and performance evaluation. Our program will include courses and seminars for the REU participants to learn the necessary infrastructure for research on computer architecture and microprocessor design. Students will perform literature surveys and design projects with faculty members. REU participants will then focus on research projects with guidance from faculty mentors. Key areas include: (1) workload reduction to reduce simulation time; (2) effective power estimation techniques using hardware and software; (3) benchmark creation for emerging workloads; (4) resource sensitivity analysis with respect to performance and power consumption; (5) development of branch prediction schemes; (6) leakage power reduction techniques; and (7) cache replacement techniques. The proposed research projects are critical issues in processor design and system-on-chip design. The findings from the REU program will help to identify new ways to improve processor performance. The proposed research topics for the REU site will benefit both industrial microprocessor design labs and academic institutes.

The REU team will aim to recruit at least 50% of the participants from underrepresented minorities, women, and students with disabilities. All research projects and reports from the REU participants will be posted on the REU web site. All REU participants are encouraged to continue working with their REU Site faculty mentors to write and publish papers in the subsequent semesters. Our overall goal is to motivate the participant undergraduate students to pursue research careers in computer architecture and microprocessor design or in science and engineering more broadly, and to take their first steps toward becoming independent researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the goal of developing a diverse, competitive, and engaged science and engineering workforce, the ESCAPE (Experimental Study on Computer Architecture and Performance Evaluation) REU program in the Electrical and Computer Engineering department at the University of Texas at San Antonio provided opportunities for research experience in computer architecture and performance evaluation to undergraduate students nationwide. This REU program emphasized engineering mind, independence and interaction in research through the designed program. Overall, a total of 37 students from twelve Universities participated in this program, resulting in several publications. We created interest in graduate program in computer engineering among the participating students by introducing them to research in computer engineering, and ten of the trained students entered various graduate schools.

We conducted three 10 week summer programs in 2011, 2012 and 2013. In these 10 week summer programs 50% of the students were from the University of Texas at San Antonio (REU site) and the other 50% of the students were selected from a national pool of applicants. Special emphasis was made to include women and underrepresented minority (URM) students in the ESCAPE REU program at the University of Texas at San Antonio. As a result we had a high female student participation rate of 26.3% and a URM student participation rate of 60.5% (the URM student count also includes female students).

A variety of student research activities resulted from the program. This program provided an excellent research opportunity for participating undergraduate students. Each student was given a research topic. The assigned research topic was selected in consultation with the students and each student was assigned a faculty mentor. Graduate student assistants were also available to help the REU participants in their research. The specific objective of each student was to complete the assigned research in the given time frame. Development of technical presentation skills was also emphasized. The students were also expected to prepare a poster, write a report and do technical presentations based on their research results. All the participants completed their assigned research activities. All of the students also did participate in poster sessions and presented their research results. Some students did high quality research work which resulted in several journal/conference papers.

Another outcome of the project concerns with graduate education. Throughout the course of the program we emphasized the importance of graduate education to the REU participants. Ten of our student participants enrolled in electrical and computer engineering graduate programs in universities such as Purdue, Columbia and University of Texas at Austin. Some of these students have already obtained their M.S. degree and are currently employed in computer engineering companies. It should be noted that, a good percentage of the participants are still completing their bachelor’s degree.

Overall this was a highly successful REU program which provided an excellent research opportunity for the participating students and a great learning experience for the faculty involved.
